title: Discrepant behavior of scoped `cfg` attribute specifier
body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->
After reading that about this feature [existing since 1.21.1](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/24396293/is-it-possible-to-conditionally-compile-a-code-block-inside-a-function) (though apparently not mentioned in the [reference](https://doc.rust-lang.org/reference/conditional-compilation.html#the-cfg-attribute)?) I wanted to use it in my project, but apparently it works differently from the "standard" `cfg` attribute, despite appearing identical syntactically:

- can't be used in global context (functions/closures only?)

This works
```rust
enum Testing {
  One,
#[cfg(feature = "test")]
  Two,
  Three
}

fn main() {
#[cfg(feature = "test")]
  let test = Testing::Two;
}
```
This throws an error
```rust
enum Testing {
  One,
#[cfg(feature = "test")] {
  Two,
}
  Three
}

fn main() {
  #[cfg(feature = "test")]
  let test = Testing::Two;
}
```
Output:
```
error: expected identifier, found `{`
 --> test.rs:3:26
  |
3 | #[cfg(feature = "test")] {
  |                          ^ expected identifier
```
---
- can't be used multiple times or combined with "standard" `cfg` attribute

This works
```rust
fn main() {
#[cfg(feature = "test")]
  let test = "world";
#[cfg(feature = "test")]
  println!("Hello {}", test);
}
```
As does this
```rust
fn main() {
#[cfg(feature = "test")] {
  let test = "world";
  println!("Hello {}", test);
}
}
```
However when mixing or using it multiple times, issues occur:
```rust
fn main() {
#[cfg(feature = "test")] {
  let test = "world";
}
#[cfg(feature = "test")]
  println!("Hello {}", test); // same output when putting this in {}
}
```
Output:
```
error[E0425]: cannot find value `test` in this scope
 --> test.rs:7:23
  |
7 |     println!("Hello {}", test);
  |                          ^^^^ not found in this scope
```
